definitions: move smoothly over ice wearing special boots with metal blades attached
roll along on a flat surface using a board or shoes with wheels
examples: She learned to skate on the frozen pond behind her house
The children skate at the ice rink every Saturday morning
Teenagers skate through the park on their inline skates daily
He decided to skate to work instead of driving today

definitions: ride on a narrow board with four wheels by pushing with one foot while balancing
examples: My brother learned to skateboard at the local skate park
Professional athletes skateboard down steep ramps performing incredible tricks

definitions: make a rough drawing quickly using simple lines without much detail
give a brief description or outline of main points or ideas
examples: The artist sketched the landscape in her notebook before painting
Students sketch their ideas before creating the final artwork design
The manager sketched out the new project plan during the meeting
Can you sketch the main events that led to this situation

definitions: cause something to turn or move at an angle instead of straight
change or present information in a way that gives false or misleading results
examples: The strong wind skewed the satellite dish on our roof yesterday
Don't skew the picture frame when you hang it on the wall
These outdated methods will skew the research data we're collecting today
Personal opinions can skew how we interpret historical events and facts

definitions: slide sideways or forward in an uncontrolled way on a slippery surface
examples: The car skidded on the icy road during the winter storm
Be careful not to skid when you brake suddenly on wet pavement

definitions: remove something floating from the surface of a liquid using a spoon or tool
read or look through text quickly to get general meaning without detailed study
examples: The cook skimmed the fat from the soup before serving dinner
We skim fallen leaves from the swimming pool every autumn morning
Students often skim the chapter before reading it thoroughly for class
I only had time to skim through the report before the meeting

definitions: be in charge of and navigate a boat or ship as its captain
examples: My uncle skippered tourist boats around the harbor for twenty years
She learned to skipper sailing vessels during her summer at sea

definitions: engage in a brief fight or minor battle between small groups of soldiers or people
examples: The border guards skirmished with smugglers trying to cross at night
Protesters skirmished with police outside the government building yesterday afternoon

definitions: defeat an opponent completely in a game or competition leaving them with no score
examples: Our basketball team skunked the visitors with a final score of 100-0
The chess master skunked three amateur players in quick succession yesterday

definitions: play tricks or engage in playful pranks and boisterous fun with others
examples: The children skylarked in the garden during their summer vacation break
Sailors used to skylark on deck when their duties were finished

definitions: make voice or video calls over the internet using computer or mobile device software
examples: We skype with our grandparents who live overseas every Sunday evening
The team skyped during lockdown to continue their weekly business meetings

definitions: rise or increase extremely quickly and suddenly to a much higher level than before
examples: Housing prices skyrocketed in the city after the new tech companies arrived
Her popularity skyrocketed after winning the international singing competition last year

definitions: reduce effort or work less hard than usual or expected
make something less tight or reduce tension in a rope or cable
examples: Don't slack off just because the supervisor left the office early
Some students slack during the last week before summer vacation begins
The sailor slacked the rope to adjust the sail position properly
You need to slack the guitar string before replacing it completely

definitions: make false spoken statements about someone that damage their reputation or character
examples: The politician accused his opponent of trying to slander him publicly
It's illegal to slander someone by spreading lies about their personal life

definitions: position or move something at an angle rather than straight up or across
present information or news with a particular bias or point of view
examples: The carpenter slanted the roof to help rain water run off easily
Slant your handwriting to the right for better cursive writing style
Some news outlets slant their coverage to appeal to specific political audiences
The documentary slanted the facts to support its controversial main argument

definitions: make a long cut with a quick sweeping movement using a sharp tool
reduce something by a large amount in a sudden dramatic way
examples: The gardener slashed through the overgrown vines with his sharp machete
The warrior slashed at his enemies with his sword during the battle
The company slashed prices by 50% during their clearance sale event
The government plans to slash funding for several public programs next year

definitions: schedule or plan something to happen at a particular time or date
criticize someone or something severely in speech or writing
examples: The meeting is slated for next Tuesday afternoon at three o'clock
Three new movies are slated to premiere at the film festival
Critics slated the new restaurant for its poor service and overpriced menu
The press slated the minister's handling of the economic crisis yesterday

definitions: kill animals for their meat in a systematic way for food production
defeat an opponent completely and overwhelmingly in a competition or conflict
examples: Farmers slaughter cattle at specific facilities designed for meat processing operations
The butcher slaughtered several chickens to sell at the morning market
Our football team slaughtered the opponents with a devastating score of 56-7
The champion boxer slaughtered every challenger who entered the ring last year

definitions: let saliva run from the mouth especially when excited or anticipating something eagerly
examples: The hungry dog slavered while watching us prepare his dinner bowl
The baby slavered all over her new toy while playing this morning

definitions: kill a person or creature in a violent way especially in battle or combat
examples: The knight vowed to slay the dragon terrorizing the nearby village
Ancient warriors would slay their enemies with swords and spears in battle

definitions: ride downhill on snow or ice using a vehicle without wheels pulled by gravity
examples: Children love to sled down the hill behind the school after snowstorms
We sledded all afternoon until our fingers were numb from cold

definitions: strike or break something using great force like a large heavy hammer would
examples: Workers sledgehammered the old concrete wall to make room for renovations
The demolition crew sledgehammered through the brick foundation all day yesterday

definitions: fall as partly frozen rain in the form of small ice pellets from clouds
examples: It started to sleet during our morning commute making roads dangerously slippery
The weather forecast says it will sleet tonight before turning to snow

definitions: search for information or investigate something carefully like a detective would do
examples: She sleuthed through old records to find her family's immigration history
Amateur historians sleuth in archives to uncover forgotten stories about their towns

definitions: turn or swing something sharply or violently to face a different direction
examples: The crane operator slewed the heavy load away from the building carefully
The ship slewed to starboard to avoid hitting the floating debris ahead

definitions: make something smooth wet and shiny often by applying oil or similar substance
examples: He slicked his hair back with gel before the job interview today
Rain slicked the roads making driving conditions dangerous during rush hour traffic

definitions: become thinner by losing weight through diet or exercise
make something smaller or reduce its size number or amount
examples: She slimmed down by ten pounds before her wedding day last summer
Many people try to slim by following strict diets and exercise routines
The company slimmed its workforce to cut operational costs this quarter
We need to slim the budget by removing unnecessary expense items immediately

definitions: throw or hurl something with force using a swinging motion
hang or suspend something loosely especially over the shoulder or between points
examples: The boy slung stones across the river with his homemade slingshot
She angrily slung her bag onto the chair after the frustrating meeting
Tourists sling their cameras around their necks while exploring the city
We slung a hammock between two trees for afternoon relaxation sessions

definitions: make a long narrow cut or opening in something using a sharp tool
examples: The tailor slit the fabric carefully to create buttonholes for the jacket
Use scissors to slit the envelope open along the top edge neatly

definitions: spill liquid carelessly causing it to splash over the edge of a container
examples: Don't slop the soup when you carry the bowl to the table
The toddler slopped milk all over the kitchen floor during breakfast today

definitions: put something into a space where it fits exactly or belongs
arrange or schedule something to fit into an available time period
examples: Slot the coin into the vending machine to buy your snack
The carpenter slotted wooden pieces together to build the bookshelf frame
Can you slot me in for an appointment next Thursday afternoon please
We slotted the presentation between the two longer meetings this morning

definitions: cast off or shed dead skin cells or an outer layer naturally
examples: Snakes slough their skin several times a year as they grow larger
Dead skin cells slough off naturally during your daily shower routine

definitions: hit someone or something very hard with the fist or a heavy object
examples: The boxer slugged his opponent with a powerful right hook punch
Don't slug your brother just because he took your toy truck

definitions: visit poor or less respectable places for curiosity or temporary entertainment
live in conditions much worse than one is accustomed to or can afford
examples: Rich tourists sometimes slum in poor neighborhoods to seem adventurous
The college students decided to slum at cheap hostels during their trip
After losing his job he had to slum in a tiny apartment downtown
The artist chose to slum in abandoned warehouses to save money for supplies

definitions: sleep in a peaceful quiet way especially for a long period of time
examples: The baby slumbered peacefully in her crib throughout the entire night
Bears slumber in their dens during the cold winter months each year

definitions: sit stand or fall heavily in a drooping way showing tiredness or defeat
decline suddenly and significantly in value amount or performance
examples: He slumped in his chair after hearing the disappointing news today
The exhausted runner slumped to the ground after crossing the finish line
Sales slumped by 40% during the economic recession last year
The team's performance slumped after their star player got injured

definitions: pronounce words in an unclear way often running sounds together
make insulting or damaging remarks about someone's character or reputation
examples: He began to slur his words after staying awake for 48 hours
The patient slurred her speech following the dental procedure this morning
The candidate tried to slur his opponent with false accusations repeatedly
It's wrong to slur people based on their background or beliefs

definitions: hit someone or something sharply with the palm of the hand
make a sharp sound by bringing two things together quickly and forcefully
examples: She smacked the mosquito that landed on her arm last night
Don't smack your little sister even if she annoys you sometimes
He smacked his lips after tasting the delicious chocolate cake dessert
The screen door smacked shut in the strong wind this afternoon

definitions: break something into pieces violently by hitting it with great force
hit strike or collide with something using great force or impact
examples: The vandals smashed the store windows during the riot last night
Be careful not to smash the delicate ornaments while packing them
The tennis player smashed the ball over the net to win the match
The car smashed into the tree after skidding on black ice

definitions: spread a sticky or greasy substance over a surface in a messy way
damage someone's reputation by spreading false accusations or rumors about them
examples: The child smeared peanut butter all over the kitchen table today
Don't smear the wet paint with your hands while it's drying
The tabloid tried to smear the actor with scandalous stories last month
Political opponents often smear each other during election campaign seasons

definitions: extract metal from rock ore by heating and melting it in a furnace
examples: The factory smelts iron ore to produce steel for construction projects
Ancient civilizations learned to smelt copper thousands of years ago

definitions: cover something thickly or completely so air cannot get through easily
suppress or stifle something completely preventing its expression or development
examples: She smothered the flames with a thick blanket to prevent spreading
Don't smother the plants with too much mulch during winter months
Overprotective parents can smother their children's independence and growth inadvertently
The government tried to smother news about the protest last week

definitions: make dirty marks or stains by rubbing or pressing something that leaves traces
examples: The child smudged chocolate on the white wall with sticky fingers
Be careful not to smudge the ink before it dries completely

definitions: move goods or people secretly and illegally into or out of a country
examples: Criminals tried to smuggle drugs across the border in hidden compartments
The refugees paid someone to smuggle them out of the war zone

definitions: eat small amounts of food between regular meals usually for pleasure rather than hunger
examples: Children often snack on cookies and milk after school each day
Try not to snack late at night if you want better sleep

definitions: catch or tear something on a sharp or rough object accidentally
obtain or grab something quickly especially when competition exists for it
examples: She snagged her new sweater on a nail sticking out from the fence
Be careful not to snag your stockings on that rough wooden chair
I managed to snag the last ticket for tonight's concert performance
Early shoppers snagged all the best deals during the holiday sale

definitions: catch an animal or person using a trap device or clever deception
examples: Hunters snare rabbits using wire loops hidden along forest paths
The detective snared the criminal with carefully gathered evidence and patience

definitions: grab or seize something quickly and suddenly often rudely or eagerly
examples: The thief snatched her purse and ran down the crowded street
The child snatched the toy from his sister's hands without asking permission

definitions: suddenly expel air from the nose and mouth involuntarily due to irritation
examples: She sneezed three times after walking through the dusty attic yesterday
People often sneeze when they look directly at bright sunlight

definitions: draw air through the nose to smell something or when crying
show contempt or disdain by drawing breath audibly through the nose
examples: The dog sniffed around the yard searching for his buried bone
She sniffed the milk to check if it was still fresh
He sniffed at their offer saying it wasn't nearly good enough
The critic sniffed dismissively at the amateur artist's work yesterday
